repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
fix for https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2159
(I started it earlier and had to finish it)

Potentially I went to wrong way, ready to comments.

comment_data.body: This looks like it breaks the general interface for `to_py_call_code`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2592,6 +2592,46 @@ def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_type=None):
             return self.base_type.find_cpp_operation_type(operator, operand_type)
         return None
 
+class CPtrToArraySliceType(CPtrType):
+    def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.to_py_function is not None:
+            return True
+        if not self.base_type.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+            return False
+
+        safe_typename = self.base_type.specialization_name()
+
+        to_py_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_py_%s" % safe_typename
+        to_tuple_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_tuple_%s" % safe_typename
+
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        context = {
+            'cname': to_py_function,
+            'to_tuple_cname': to_tuple_function,
+            'base_type': self.base_type,
+        }
+        env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "carray_slice.to_py", "CConvert.pyx",
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
+            context=context, compiler_directives=dict(env.global_scope().directives)))
+        self.to_tuple_function = to_tuple_function
+        self.to_py_function = to_py_function
+        return True
+
+    def to_py_call_code(self, source_code, start_code, stop_code, result_code, result_type, to_py_function=None):

comment_data.body:
Can you ever end up with `arg` as something that isn't a `SliceIndexNode`? For example:

    a = some_array[1:10]
    return a

Could `a` pick up the type from the indexing operation, but the coercion would happen to a `NameNode`?

comment_data.body: Yes. It seems to me that going through an implementation tree node would be better than going through the type system for this. A sliced array isn't really a type by itself.

comment_data.body: A lot can happen between now and code generation time, so we should read the type again in `generate_result_code()` and not store it here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13291,6 +13302,56 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
         self.generate_gotref(code)
 
 
+class CoerceSliceCArrayToList(CoercionNode):
+    # This node is used to convert a Slice of C array to c-array
+    is_temp = 1
+    type = py_object_type
+    
+    def __init__(self, arg, env, type=py_object_type):
+        self.el_type = arg.base.type.base_type

comment_data.body:
There is no guarantee that these are ints. They might be C compiler macro names, `sizeof(sometype)`, or whatever. But we can calculate this size at runtime and let the C compiler fold it for us if it can. We don't actually need to know it for the code generation.

Note also that the slice length might be zero or negative. We need to test and handle that. Min and max `Py_ssize_t` / `size_t` values are also usually worth testing, e.g. the empty slice `[max:min]`.

You can use `__Pyx_is_valid_index()` for bounds checking, but should take a look at the `boundscheck` and `wraparound` directives as well, which should disable these checks. Wraparound can also be made to work with a known array length. There is a lot of example code in `StringTools.c`.

Edit: In fact, feel free to use a Cython implemented utility function for this, instead of generating the conversion code with string formatting. See the `carray` conversion functions in `CConvert.pyx`.

+    is_temp = 1

+    
+    def __init__(self, arg, env, type=py_object_type):

+        sliceSize = int(stop) - int(start)

comment_data.body: I would name it `c_array_slice.to_py` or `c_ptr_slice.to_py`, because with `c_slice` it's not clear what it refers to – a slice of what?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

     return t

+#################### c_slice.to_py ####################

comment_data.body: It would be nice if we could support `tuple` creation as well, by looking at the actual `dst_type`. You can write a test for that with a `cpdef` test function that has `tuple` as return type, and then return a C array slice from it. Or cast to `<tuple>`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5026,6 +5026,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
                     "default encoding required for conversion from '%s' to '%s'" %
                     (self.base.type, dst_type))
             self.type = dst_type
+        elif dst_type.is_pyobject and self.base.type.is_array:
+            return CoerceSliceCArrayToList(self, env)

comment_data.body:
This is a bit funny – why is there a `SliceIndexNode` at all, when the work is done by the `CoerceSliceArrayToList` node that wraps it? I think that's coupling both nodes too tightly.

Do we need the coercion node at all? Can't the `SliceIndexNode` simply return the Python tuple or list, and build it itself? Basically, if `self.base` is a C array or C pointer (we need tests for both), and `self.type` is `list_type` or `tuple_type`, then call the slice copying function. You can create an appropriately configured `SliceIndexNode` in its `coerce_to()` method and just return that.

I think we can also raise compile time errors when trying to coerce a C array to any builtin or extension type other than `list`/`tuple`. Oh, and `set`/`frozenset`, because why not support `<frozenset>intptr[:10]` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         return super(SliceIndexNode, self).coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
     def generate_result_code(self, code):
+        base_result = self.base.result()
+        result = self.result()
+
         if not self.type.is_pyobject:
-            error(self.pos,
-                  "Slicing is not currently supported for '%s'." % self.type)
+            if self.base.type.is_array:
+                code.putln("%s = %s;" % (result, base_result))

comment_data.body: I think we should also have (error) tests for the case that these are not integers.

comment_data.body:
What if someone passes negative numbers?
And I think we also have to take the `boundscheck` and `wraparound` directives into account.

Note that there is a slice bounds calculation function coming in from PR #3600, `__Pyx_PySlice_AdjustIndices()`, which I think we can best reuse here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -130,3 +130,21 @@ cdef inline tuple {{to_tuple_cname}}({{base_type}} *v, Py_ssize_t length):
         Py_INCREF(value)
         PyTuple_SET_ITEM(t, i, value)
     return t
+
+#################### c_slice.to_py ####################
+
+cdef extern from *:
+    void Py_INCREF(object o)
+    list PyList_New(Py_ssize_t size)
+    void PyList_SET_ITEM(object  p, Py_ssize_t pos, object o)
+
+@cname("{{cname}}")
+cdef inline list {{cname}}({{base_type}} *v, Py_ssize_t fromIdx, Py_ssize_t toIdx):
+    cdef size_t i
+    cdef object value
+    l = PyList_New(toIdx - fromIdx)
+    for i in range(<size_t>fromIdx, <size_t>toIdx):

comment_data.body:
The utility code should not get compiled with whatever directives the users have set for their own code. It should be well defined.

Although, that's not entirely true. Anything that changes coercions, specifically the `c_string_type` and `c_string_encoding` directives, should best be honoured for the item conversion. E.g. a sliced `char[][]` should turn into a list with items of the user requested string type. That means we also need tests for that. You can put those into the respective `*_auto_encoding.pyx` test modules.

I think we need to build a dict of well selected directives here.

comment_data.body: Hmm, no, I meant that the `SliceIndexNode` can do the copying of the array slice part itself, rather than having a separate node do it instead. It's the purpose of the `SliceIndexNode` to do the slicing, whatever the result is. And if the result is calculated by a copy function, so be it. But it's still up to the `SliceIndexNode` to call that function, right here in this place.

commit.message: Tests for coercion of sliced C array
Coercion for sliced C array has been added

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: [wip]Coercing sliced array to Python  object
